text: welcome to today's webinar entitled what is AWS so today's agenda really is to give
you an overview of what AWS is and why people are using it to take a thousand
foot view on all the services in the toolbox or as many as we can cover in the time that we have it's a broad U
portfolio of services and products that we offer and a look at the top two questions really that people have When
approaching AWS particularly from an Enterprise perspective so let's crack on with with
that so a bit of background really so clearly I'm from Amazon and Amazon web
services is part of the amazon.com family of businesses and there are three main parts to that family one being the
consumer business where we've all probably got an account and we've ordered gifts maybe at Christmas time uh
there's a seller business in that retail e-commerce infrastructure enables third parties to sell through the
infrastructure and that's really part of the story of where Amazon web services came from then of course is the it
infrastructure side the cloud computing business with hundreds of thousands of customers on that platform Amazon web
services now I often get asked the question how did Amazon retail get into
cloud computing if you're like how did they go from packing boxes in distribution centers to unpacking server
boxes in data centers and racking them back on shelves well the journey started for us over 10 years ago and it's been
in the making for that sort of time 6 years ago Amazon web services was born but the journey to that point really
started with the enablement of those sellers on Amazon retail because we started to slice the infrastructure that
we were providing uh supporting our e-commerce businesses up and offering it to third parties to use for third
parties to self through as part of that Journey we got quite smart on how we deployed applications on a scalable and
Global basis and we move from monolithic if you like exotic hardware and software to commodity highly distributed Ed
systems and consistent deployments across the globe we also started some
early sort of test phay into the developer Community because one of the very first web services that we deployed
was actually a catalog search so a simple web service API on top of the Amazon book catalog enabled third
parties to search our book catalog and embed results in their own websites and the uptake on that really took us by
surprise um it went went ballistic so we took a step back and we said you know what if we could wrap everything that
we're doing now in terms of uh service orientation in terms of provisioning of systems globally to support our
e-commerce and our seller businesses and we did the same thing for all of that wrapped as a web service and that's
really where AWS came from it was that blinding flash of the obvious that we can do it for ourselves therefore we can
offer it to other people via web service API so six years ago now AWS mission
statement was set and it's exactly the same now as it was then and it's to enable businesses and developers to use
web services to build scalable sophisticated applications and it's worth noting that web services it says
it in our name but that's really what people are now calling the cloud and the AWS Cloud will use the terms inter
interchangeably one myth to bust of course being part of a retail organization I often get asked what
happens at Christmas will people that have Compu resources in your elastic compute Cloud um get those resources
taken back when Amazon needs extra capacity to process the Christmas orders and that's absolutely not the case
Amazon web services is not excess capacity from the retail organization was set up as a strategic part of the
business it's a business in its own right Amazon retail is a customer of that business and testament to the
Strategic nature and the size of this business is that most popular internet businesses are powered by Amazon web
services so some logos there that I'm sure you'll recognize from Instagram Pinterest Etsy and so
but it's not just the latest Internet uh startups or Internet phenomenons that are on
AWS it's also trusted by Enterprises so again out of those hundreds of thousands

Samsung Smart TVs with the Smart Hub application behind them or in you know
looking at media on the guardian and so on we're using Amazon web services and un shapable form so it's trusted by
Enterprises and startups alike an interesting statistic on Amazon
web services that each day AWS adds the equivalent server capacity to power Amazon retail when it was A5 billion
Enterprise now that was back in 2003 and a 5.2 billion retail business we had
7,800 employees give or take and we had a whole lot of servers behind the scenes
running that infrastructure another statistic which is interesting which is the objects in
storage in our simple storage service S3 simple storage service allows you to store anything from one BTE to 5
terabytes in size if you use dropbox you're using S3 if you use Spotify you're streaming music from S3 and many
different solutions back themselves onto S3 and we've just surpassed the end of last year 1.3 trillion objects in
storage and at the peak transaction rate we're topping 835 transactions per second reading and writing into and out
of that platform so it's a significant operation it's a high scale uh we
understand how to operate systems at high availability and that's a lot of objects to manage so the success of it
sort of breeds off its own sort of Statistics another stat which is a new
stat that we're releasing is that 3.7 million clusters or EMR jobs elastic map
produced this is hadu a way to parallelize the computational analysis of large data sets we can see
the curve growing so more and more people are spinning up clusters of computers to analyze data sets that
previously it was uneconomic or unachievable on a time frame to do so so ammr jobs are on the curve growth as
well and Innovation is really in our DNA so we're always innovating on behalf of
our customers because the more we innovate the more services we provide to you the more you'll use and consume AWS
and in the first 11 months of 2012 we released 158 new features now those dots
are days in the month where we released one or more features so it's an ongoing activity for us we're releasing new
features all of the time so what is this all about really what is AWS at its heart well the
concept of utility computing is where it's all at now if you think about a utility like
electricity um when you use electricity you expect it to be there um when you
plug a plug into a socket you expect it to turn on when you turn the switch so it's on demand you only expect to pay
for what you use and you expect it to be the same wherever you plug in across the grid and if you think about Computing or
infrastructure inside a data center what we're doing at Amazon web services is wrapping that data center in those same
properties making it on demand you only pay for what you use it's uniform wherever you use it within the global
infrastructure structure and it's highly available it's always there when you need it so you can trust and rely upon it and the trick is is that we wrapped
all of that infrastructure if you like wrapped the data center in an API so that you can access anything that goes
on inside that data center from standing up some compute to do some install some server software for example to
installing instantiating a database to Distributing content for a global distribution Network to manage storage
workflow security and so so on uh P youo uniform and highly
available nature all comes into play via that single consistent
API now just as you would plug into a grid um and of to acquire a utility like
electricity the AWS network is a global one and it sits on what we call fundamental regions around the world so
regions are uh places where you can choose to run your compute workload so
to store data in something like S3 for example and once you choose to run something in that region it will never
leave that region so they're geographically isolated so they useful constructs for in terms of data
jurisdiction if you want to keep something within the EU place it in the EU region within a region we have the
concept of availability zones availability zones are considered physically distinct data centers or
collections of data centers and there are two or more availability zones in a region uh so you can build highly
available applic ations by architecting across availability zones and some of the services that I'll take you through
later are fundamentally built across availability zones by Nature so they're already highly available or multi-az as
we call them then lastly we have uh Edge locations so whether you're wanting to
respond to DNS queries or you want to push static content or stream video media to people around the globe um we
have Edge locations that enable you to serve those customer custers as fast as possible from the locations that that
they're at so they're not always traversing a Global Network to to get response from your applications or
services that can obviously get responses from Edge locations too now all of this as I said before is
available at the end of a web service call and here are two simple command line uh commands that wrap a web service
call produce a soap command behind the scenes then instantiate some servers in our EU region we're instantiating three
small small servers and five medium servers based upon different what we call machine images which are freeze
stried copies or or static copies of of machines installed software and so on that when you start them they come up
being a particular Flavor now those just as easily could be a stood up in our one
of our US regions and here I'm bringing some extra large instances up in the US East so you can see at the simple call
of a web service I can programmatically access the resources in the data center and of course I can also turn them off
programmatic atically as well and this is drastically different from the way you'd approach traditional data centers
and collocation where the lead cycle the planning cycle the capital investment and so on would inhibit being able to
start a server and stop it within the hour now all of these web services calls
wrap other services as well so by way of example I'm here authorizing a firewall
port at the top left of my screen and I'm creating elastic load balance right at the bottom left and I'm defining an
auto scale group where I can have a group of servers that will be a minimum of two servers in a region but can grow
in a pool up to 200 based upon some properties but of course all of those
web services also get wrapped up into a console so you can graphically Drive the Amazon web services infrastructure via
the AWS console too okay so given that infrastructure
and that Global footprint why are customers adopting Cloud Compu well the first reason that they're
adopting them is that it's a variable expense platform that pays you go nature so they can replace capital expenditure
with a variable expense you know move things off from a a complex approval process onto a monthly pay as you go so
versus the physical installation they might have to go through on on premise the acquisition the raising of purchase
orders the the the stumping up of the cach in advance to acquire some physical Hardware with AWS it's cost you nothing
to get started and you'll only pay for what you use another reason why customers are
adopting cloud is economies of scale because we have so many customers on the platform they can achieve a lower
variable expense than if they were trying to implement some sort of of cloud computing model within their own
facilities so beyond virtualization part of being a with a large set of customers
enables us to innovate on behalf of all of you and for us to keep prices as low as possible across the
board so if you look at people like Samsung Commonwealth Bank of for square Samsung with their Smart Hub application
which drives the latest Smart TVs save $34 million on using AWS in the first
instance versus using some sort of virtualized infrastructure within their own
facilities and we often talk about a virtuous cycle and if you think about how we can inject more AWS usage we
provide new features new Services we develop an ecosystem that enables you to
do more on the platform and therefore we get more usage of the platform that drives economies of scale and allows us
to innovate at very large scale around the technology that we provide so that we can provide Technologies at the
lowest cost and that enables us then to pass on those costs and price reductions to you so over 2006 since we were we
started off on this journey 23 price reductions and we're always trying to pass on those benefits back to you so
that the cycle repeats another reason why customers are adopting cloud computing is this idea of
elastic capacity I no need to guess capacity requirements and therefore overr provision some sort of seller
resources you have in a traditional data center if you look at these curves where uh the blue line is what I predicted the
workload on my application or service to be and the Orange Line being the actual
demand that hits me there are two real portions that can be Illustrated on this chart is at the bottom left where I've
got less demand than I've predicted then I have waste I've over provision the physical resources I bought too much kit
I've spent too much time scaling out systems and so on versus when the actual
demand catches us out and we don't have enough capacity customer dissatisfaction results we can't service our customers
we lose transactions and revenue people go and find another website to browse to get their responses quicker
so elastic capacity is all about following the curve with the right amount of resources at the right point in time balanced resources only paying
for what you need to get the job done and we'll illustrate that point through some of the services uh as I go into the
tool boox today another reason is Speed and Agility so you can get infrastructure in
minutes not weeks and I've hinted at this before so if you think about some of the customers and their deployment
Times News Limited in Australia part of news into news corporation reducing
application deployment times from two months to go from the start of a process to provisioned in live to 3 days because
at the end of an API call they can configure infrastructure they don't have to wait for a ticket to be queed they
don't have to wait for Hardware to be provisioned or for virtualized space to be made available and again the story
repeats across our customer base something which is unachievable with physical resources so in an Old World
infrastructure in weeks and I'm sure we've all being in the que ver like the diagram on the left where we're our
ticket is is stuck in a queue and we're waiting on constrained resources that are in a very expensive data center to
become available versus adding a new development environment the click of a button adding a new production
environment um adding a thousand servers removing a thousand servers all at the click of a button that can be wrapped
against those command calls against our apis because of that Speed and Agility
as well you can experiment often and fail quickly at a low cost so that Fosters Innovation versus you know
having to justify acquiring resources to take a bit of a risk on a service or a
product with Amazon we find that the the the speed at which customers innovate
and the speed at which products and services are released and then they're iterated upon and maybe pivoted upon is
far increased versus what would happen traditionally where the resources are constrained and there's a drag placed
upon that Innovation cycle next up people can focus on a business because they're no longer diff uh
focusing on what we call undifferentiated heavy it lifting because we take care of things like data
centers Power Cooling cabling and so on so you don't have to you just need to
really focus upon the business that you're delivering not on the need to configure new software build new data
centers install new hardware and so on so we take away the undifferentiated high it lifting
another last point is that customers can access um a Global Network and can go
Global in minutes and reach a global audience there are many examples in the customer base where this has happened
small companies or smaller ideas within larger companies that have' really taken off and they've needed to expand rapidly
and they've been able to do so over the AWS Network by taking an application and deploying it across multiple regions and

provision capacity was about 15% over Peak so during the month of November and
the build up to that end Peak that have to bring in new hardware rack and stack it bring it online test it and so on and
that was resulting in 76% wasted unused capacity okay so stuff
that was sat idle versus 24% utilization of those machines the software the

the same thing happened in the European business so since that transition onto AWS the
curve now looks like this so real statistics these are provisioned instances to handle particular workloads

off they're not paying for them another example example of elastic
capacity in action is a company called Animoto Animoto lets you upload an MP3
file and arrange of photographs and it will do some clever things and mix the photos into a movie based upon the beats
and the music I'll give you a movie back that you can then download now they had the bright idea that in 2008 where they

that were tagged inside those photographs would be notified that they're in a movie would they like to

to 5,000 in three days now they architected around AWS using some of the
technologies that I'll show you today and they've architected with best principles such that they were able to sit back and watch that growth happen
automatically their servers elastically grew using a concept called autoscaling
and when the peak of demand passed the autoscaling brought back the number of services supporting the the application
and the website and they stopped paying for the resources they only paid it just for what they needed to get the job done something which would be unachievable
for three guys if they'd have to go and rack and stack physical kit okay so that's a bit of background
so now let's have a bit of a deep dive on the services in the toolbox so there are many many services in the toolbox
and I'll try and give you some of the key ones and describe what they do so at least you have a broad understanding of
the capabilities of the tools in the portfolio and I'll do that based upon a reference model so a classic sort of
Enterprise stack wedding cake so we'll start at the bottom and we'll end up at the top at deployment Administration
services so I've already mentioned at the global infrastructure layer we have regions so these are independent
collection of AWS resources and a defined geography so for example if you want to use S3 you would choose a region
for your bucket to be hosted if you want to start an ec2 instance a virtual machine you choose a region for which
you want to deploy it too okay so these are geographically isolated and form a solid foundation for meeting some of
your location dependent uh privacy and compliance requirements within a region we have
availability zones and these are cons think about these as being distinct data centers separate power separate flood
planes and so on so that if you deploy an ec2 server into a region and you
deploy it across more than one availability Zone you buy you have a a high availability configuration or you
have the bedrock in order to build ha applications and lastly I've mentioned these Edge locations servicing things
like our Global DNS provide service called Route 53 and cloudfront content delivery
Network so above those global infrastructure sort of foundation Services we then have some networking
Services which you should be aware of um firstly we a enable you to connect
directly between your data center and an AWS facility and you can do that via
different locations where you can if you like cross connect in those facilities and you can effectively buy a 1 gig or
10 gig Port dedicated bandwidth private line into AWS so if you look at AWS as
something that you want to host privately facing services in versus maybe public internet services Direct
Connect gives you consistency around that connection and over Direct Connect and indeed the internet you can layer a
VPN so you can cure your tunnel into AWS we provide the hardware endpoints that
you effectively rent by the hour inside our facilities and you have a hardware endpoint maybe a Cisco router at your
end you download the configuration and you'll establish a VPN connection across the internet or indeed against a direct
connect connection once you've done these things you can also take a slice of the AWS Cloud we have a concept
called virtual private Cloud that enables you to like separate your sales from General Network traffic extend your
your network address ranges into AWS Define subnets routing tables and so on
giving you a degree of extra control around the networking that goes on an AWS still on shared resources in terms
of a a public Cloud offering but you have separation all the way down to the network layer now so you can Define your
own address ranges and be confident of that separation at that layer last and the networking space
slightly different from fundamental networking Services is Route 53 so we have a Route 53 Global DNS service that
has one really interesting property that you should take away of yourselves today is that it gives 100% request reply
guarantee so if you're providing an internet facing service and your DNS provider doesn't direct your customers
to your application servers you may as well not have any application servers there so if your DNS fails that's a bad
thing you're not even getting customers to your front door so having a DNS backbone that you can trust is sort of
key to any internet facing service and Route 53 provide you with those slas and
guarantees then we're moving up into like the fundamental building blocks of
of most applications built within the AWS cloud and that is elastic compute Cloud ec2 so this is where you can stand
up a server uh a server range in size from a very small called a micro from 2
cents an hour you only pay for what you use all of these servers have hourly rates and you can go up to very large
cluster computes you know we can go up to instance sizes with 200 40 gab of of memory in an instance again you're only
paying the hourly rate for what you want to use you can have Linux distributions or you can have Windows distributions so
if you want to stand up a Windows 2013 server the price of that license for that server is included in the hourly
rate so you get full rout administrator access this is your server to do what you wish with and it's disposable you
can come and go on this you can acquire them when you need them you can throw them away when you're done and one of
the really interesting things around pricing models for these things is that you have an ond demand price but if you
have servers you're running 24 by7 you can reserve them and ultimately pay less and have a really good Roi over 6 to9
months you can also access some of the the maybe more exotic servers over a
spot instance price maybe if you're running a very large Hadoop jobs and you want to acquire some larger server types
to consume and process very large sets of data you can do that on the spot market so essentially bidding on unused
capacity and we'll give you a much reducer price um on the the the understanding that if we the price goes
above what you're bidding then you'll lose that server so some really interesting um use cases for using spot
reserved instances can save you loads of money and On Demand you can just obviously click and go right there and
then wrapping ec2 and those examples are given you like of Amazon retail or or
Animoto they use something called Auto scaling so Auto scaling is the frame work within AWS that enables you to add
more servers or take servers away based upon some sort of triggers so it gives you can control over the the pool of
resources to support some sort of workload so it could be that this group
here that I've shown you was a minimum of four and a maximum of 200 it could grow based upon the CPU load on average
across all those servers as it goes above a threshold add some more servers as it goes below a threshold take them
away it could be latency is seen from a you know your web users it could be the depth of a queue of messages that you're
needing to process on a batch job as the queue grows add more servers and so on it can also be done by schedule or
manually so you could have autoscaling take effect on a Friday night at your peak of demand you pre-warm you add more
servers and on Saturday morning you take them away again on a defined schedule so aut scale is the tool that enables you
to grow and shrink the ECT resources behind some sort of application
if you've got multiple application servers or web servers or whatever happens to be running on these E2
instances often you need to load balance requests across them so traditionally
you might install a software load balancer or you might install a Cisco or an F5 piece of Hardware you might have
to then deploy those in an ha fashion inside your data centers and then you'd have to string them together maybe
across data centers for for failover elastic load balancer is our virtualized
equivalent of those things so it's a an elastic load balancer service operates at a regional level and can load balance
across instances sat in multiple availability zones in a region and it automatically takes instances in and out
of service depending upon whether it works out if they're unhealthy or healthy another common use case is doing
SSL offload as well it's you can put your choose your ciphers upgrad your keys into the load balancer and then you
can offload that that load from your backend servers as well
then we move from compute to storage so S3 is a fundamental Bedrock of many
different applications out there so compute on ec2 data often in S3 and S3
is an object storage platform so it think of it as as a very very large
scalable elastic web server for serving objects of any type from one BTE to 5
terabytes in size as I said before if you're using Dropbox your files are stored in S3 if you're streaming music
from Spotify your music files are streaming out of S3 now the unique thing
about S3 is that we store copies of data multiple times across multiple physical facilities to achieve what we call 11
nines durability of objects so the system is designed to support 11 nines of durability so in reality what that
means is that once data is an S3 it's kept and any problems with any copies
that data automatically um repaired and your data is safe and secure so you can
store anything in here whether it be backups logs static content for websites and it goes beyond simple object storage
it versions objects you can put life cycle policies around it to push data into something called glacia which I'll
talk about later as well so as I said before S3 Spotify is
one of the most common and well-known examples of of of Hosting data think about the volume of media that's there
the number of requests made against that service and S3 is a fundamental backbone of
Spotify so when Emil the operations director at Spotify was looking for a
service he couldn't grow his physical storage he couldn't do enough capacity
planning he couldn't get the sums right in order to provide a physical storage platform to back Spotify and the one
thing that he took away from this is that is a large scale platform and it can grow to meet his needs he doesn't
need to do capacity planning again because it's unlimited storage in S3 you
with your AWS account you might sign up for today you can access unlimited S3
storage now another part of storage is backed onto instances and it's called elastic Block store so when you have an
instance a computer running you have what we' call a virtual disc drive if you like an elastic Block store so this
is a block storage device as opposed to um object storage device like S3 so this
is where when you launch an instance the operating system is installed and it will boot from these drives and you can
add more or less of these drives to your instances you can have um one terabyte in size of an EBS volume and of course
you have multiple of those volumes but it integrates with uh snapshotting features so you can take a snapshot an
instant copy of a drive and push that into S3 for storage so you can recover or clone drives you can move EVS volumes
between instances so if an instance has a problem you can just take the OBS volume and start a new instance from it
so this is the fundamental formatting that you can put across it to support a Windows Os or a Linux
OS and I mentioned glassier as well so glassier is built like S3 in terms of
the same sort of durability levels but it's designed such that we put items in
very sort of long-term archive the idea being is that you can do that very cheaply in glassier because we don't
expect you to retrieve objects very often so you only start really paying
when you go above a threshold of the amount of archives you're retrieving and it takes about 3 to 5 hours to retrieve
an archive from glacia once it's in there now one of the really neat things is that S3 is integrated to glacia and
you can set policies on S3 that would say these objects maybe these log files
after 6 months I want them archived in glacia and after 5 years I want them
deleted from glassier here so there is an assumption that those those objects won't want to be accessed and if you do
it's probably under some audit or special Condition it's probably the only copy of those logs you've got but you can place them in glassier and
effectively do what you traditionally do with tape but do it
online next along the list is databases so databases very common um and we take
away if you like the mark of managing a database platform providing relational database service or the database as a
service so there's no need for you to install the manage databases on ec2 instances you can of course if you're
looking for a variant of database that we don't provide in RDS we currently support Oracle MySQL and mssql server so
they're preconfigured you just choose how big your database you want you choose when uh we can do patching of
that instance you choose whether you want it to be multi- availability zone so that will handle the failure for you
if you want read replicas and so on and then we'll stand your update instance give you an endo and we'll manage
everything from there all in for you take automated backup so you can go back to a point in time and recover data any
point in time so it really takes away a load of the effort of managing a database server and it's very cost
effective you can even use this within the free tier within AWS on a
micro so another popular example of somebody that's that uses RDS as a Bedrock to their online facing services
like Forum frad site content to support their games is Sega so they have RDS in
a multi-az deployment so that means that there's a master in one availability Zone a slave in another and that will
handle the failover of any problems occur and within that we're handling live game metadata and user generated
content from a range of titles and it takes away the pain of their managing the timec consuming administrative task
normally associated with setting up a highly scalable fault toer and relational database structure lets them
get on with the dealing with the production of great content and great games
another database platform is Dynamo DB Dynamo DB is a nosql data store so this
is solving a challenge of non-relational structures very high scale very high
volume where you're looking for consistent throughput performance regardless of scale traditionally
relational databases degrade when they become very very large difficult to maintain you have to Shard them
partition them Dynamo DB solves that by allowing you to just dial up the provision capacity your throughput you
require per table so if you have one very large table and you want um and
you're getting hit on that table very very often consider maybe that being moved into Dynamo and will'll handle all
the clustering all the partitioning of the data and you'll only pay for the capacity you want in terms of read writes per second against that table
it's all backed by SSD Hardware so it's super fast it's secure and it integrates of all the different services and
particularly elastic map produce which will come on to in a little while Beyond networking compute and
storage and databases there are then middleware type services that AWS offer
so if you're looking to um connect application components or decouple them if you like via a queuing system you
might be using Java messaging system you might be backing those um messages onto
a database so using the JMS against an Oracle database or what have you to create a persistent reliable queuing
infrastructure sqs the simple queuing service provides you with that at regional service level so just like S3
you can drop a message into Q um you can unlimited number of messages in those cues and they're redundantly stored
across multiple availability zones so you can simply pop a message in and then pull it out when you're ready so great for decoupling workloads and for
handling some elastic maybe batch processing we also have simple workflow
where your uh workflows are more complex than maybe are practical to support over just simple qqs so where you need to
make decisions where you need to handle metadata where you need to handle roll back auditing and so on swf is a
framework that enables you to coordinate tasks in some sort of sequence and one of the customers that use this is NASA
JPL so this is um uh opportunity who is
still moving on Mars years after he was supposed to have um have failed and his
workflow through swf is around taking imagery from the Rope back through relay satellites JPL and
essentially taking left and right images doing some warping actions on them stereo matching creating a 3D map and
tiling things together to create a picture pictures which are presented to The Operators and to the public on NASA
websites and there images like this so this is a a tiled image of many different fragments that are pulled
together using a simple workflow in AWS and there we can see the tire tracks of where this this Rover has been but that
platform is still in news today and the Curiosity Rover um that's currently
doing experiments on Mars again all the bits coming back from Mars are passing through a simple workflow and at the
same time as JPL Engineers received the first images of it landing on Mars um we
did as public to all published through AWS and there's an image from the latest
um Rover there one of the first images tiled together so one of the things that NASA
JPL do is is integrate ec2 Resources with their on premise resources using
simple workflow so they were able to coordinate between existing assets and cloud-based assets so that's quite a
useful tool where you already have Compu resources you wish to use some other services quickly is cloud
search so Amazon retail have the A9 search engine behind their websites that
